L., Eisenhardt, P. R. M., Mainzer, A. K., et al. 2010, AJ, 140, 1868\n\n                \n                                                            <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/#abs/2010AJ....140.1868W/abstract\">\n                                                    [NASA ADS]\n                                                </a>\n                                                                                <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\">\n                                                    [CrossRef]\n                                                </a>\n                                    \n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?author=Wright%2C+E.+L.%2C+Eisenhardt%2C+P.+R.%2C+Mainzer%2C+A.+K.&journal=AJ&volume=140&issue=6&pages=-1868&publication_year=2010&issn=0004-6256%2C1538-3881\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R76\"></a>Wynne, R. A., &amp; Schechter, P. L. 2018, MIT Undergrad. Res. J., submitted [<a href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.06151\" target=\"_blank\">arXiv:1808.06151</a>]\n\n                \n                \n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?author=Wynne%2C+R.+A.%2C+%26amp%3B+Schechter%2C+P.+L.&publication_year=2018\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R77\"></a>Zavala, J. A., Monta\u00f1a, A., Hughes, D. H., et al. 2018, Nat. Astron., 2, 56\n\n                \n                                                            <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/#abs/2018NatAs...2...56Z/abstract\">\n                                                    [NASA ADS]\n                                                </a>\n                                                                                <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.1038/s41550-017-0297-8\">\n                                                    [CrossRef]\n                                                </a>\n                                    \n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?author=Zavala%2C+J.+A.%2C+Monta%C3%B1a%2C+A.%2C+Hughes%2C+D.+H.&journal=Nat.+Astron.&volume=2&issue=1&pages=56&publication_year=2018&issn=2397-3366\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                </ol>\n    </div>\n\n\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix A:  Non-singular isothermal ellipsoid lens model in the presence of an external shear</h2>\n<p>The non-singular isothermal ellipsoid lens model in the presence of an external shear (NSIEg) is characterized by <i>&#954;</i>, the dimensionless surface mass density projected in the lens plane and defined by</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq1\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-eq1.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.1)</span></span></p>\n<p>where the coordinates (<i>x</i>,&#8198;<i>y</i>) locate a position in the lens plane, <i>s</i> corresponds to the deflector core radius, <i>q</i> is the ratio of the minor to the major axes of the elliptical isodensity contours, and <i>b</i> is considered here as a normalizing factor. From <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R39\">Keeton &amp; Kochanek (1998)</a>, the two components of the corresponding scaled deflection angle, <b><i>&#945;</i></b>, are given by</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq2\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-eq2.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.2)</span></span></p>\n<p>and</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq3\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-eq3.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.3)</span></span></p>\n<p>where <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-eq4.gif\"></span> is defined as the eccentricity of the isodensity contours, and <i>&#968;</i><sup>2</sup>&#8196;=&#8196;<i>q</i><sup>2</sup>(<i>s</i><sup>2</sup>+<i>x</i><sup>2</sup>)&#8197;+&#8197;<i>y</i><sup>2</sup>. The contribution of more distant massive objects to the deflection is taken into account through an external shear term of the form</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq5\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-eq5.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.4)</span></span></p>\n<p>where <i>&#947;</i> is the shear intensity and <i>&#969;</i> its orientation. Finally, the position <b><i>&#952;</i></b><sub><b><i>s</i></b></sub>&#8196;=&#8196;(<i>x</i><sub>s</sub>,<i>y</i><sub>s</sub>) of a point-like source is related to a lensed image position <b><i>&#952;</i></b>&#8196;=&#8196;(<i>x</i>,<i>y</i>) through the so-called lens equation</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD5\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq6\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-eq6.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.5)</span></span></p>\n<p>and the associated magnification factor <i>&#956;</i>(<b><i>&#952;</i></b>) is then defined by</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD6\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq7\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-eq7.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(A.6)</span></span></p>\n<p>where the Jacobian matrix A(<b><i>&#952;</i></b>)&#8197;=&#8197;&#8706;<b><i>&#952;</i></b><sub><b><i>s</i></b></sub>(<b><i>&#952;</i></b>)/&#8706;<b><i>&#952;</i></b> is called the amplification matrix.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix B:  Gaia GraL catalogue of clusters from Gaia DR2 sources</h2>\n<p>The <i>Gaia</i> GraL catalogue of clusters from <i>Gaia</i> DR2 sources is available at the CDS. The catalogue is composed of all 2 129 659 clusters identified in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S2\">2</a> along with the ERT probabilities computed for each of them (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S3\">3</a>). For ease of identifying the images constituting each cluster and to facilitate the cross-match against other catalogues based on the individual components of the clusters, each entry from the catalogue corresponds to a single <i>Gaia</i> DR2 source within the cluster. Consequently, clusters composed of three and four images have, respectively, three and four associated entries in the catalogue along with the fields that are common to the cluster they belong to. The fields constituting each row of the catalogue are detailed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#T4\">B.1</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table B.1.</span></a><p>Description of the fields contained in the <i>Gaia</i> GraL catalogue of clusters from <i>Gaia</i> DR2 sources.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>Our objective here is not to provide a list of GL candidates, as we do in Sects. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S8\">3.4.1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S9\">3.4.2</a>, but to provide the user with a catalogue that can easily provide hints on the lensing nature of some of the observational targets, at least regarding GLs that are reproducible through a NSIEg lens model. This approach also justifies the inclusion of clusters located in regions of the sky we know to be densely populated and where the contamination rate of GL candidates will typically be very high. The removal of the clusters having a field density higher than <i>&#961;</i>&#8196;&gt;&#8196;3&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>4</sup> objects deg<sup>&#8722;2</sup> effectively reduces their number by a factor of ten (205 004 remaining clusters).</p>\n<p>To our knowledge, the present catalogue is the first to provide a discriminating value associated with each cluster that reflects the ability for a given GL model to reproduce the observed configuration of images. These ERT probabilities can provide a straight binary classification as, for example, 96.31% of the four-image configurations have <i>P</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;0.5, whereas 86.11% of the three-image configurations have <i>P</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;0.9. The threshold we set on <i>P</i> are obviously application-dependent and should be set in agreement with the ROC curves we described in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S3\">3</a>. Finally, in a conservative approach, we do not set any cut on the difference in colour between images of the clusters, &#916;(<i>G</i><sub>BP</sub>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>G</i><sub>RP</sub>). However, whenever they are available they provide an important criterion for identifying GLs as we do not expect the colours to vary much between the images of GLs (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S7\">3.4</a> for examples).</p>\n\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"tabs\"></a>All Tables</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1.</span></a><p>List of all spectroscopically confirmed quadruply-imaged systems having <i>N</i><sub>img</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;3,&#8198;4 components detected in <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#T1\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2.</span></a><p>Range of parameters explored to produce the simulated lens catalogues from a NSIEg lens model.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#T2\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3.</span></a><p>List of GL candidates.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#T3\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table B.1.</span></a><p>Description of the fields contained in the <i>Gaia</i> GraL catalogue of clusters from <i>Gaia</i> DR2 sources.</p>\n<div class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#T4\">In the text</a></div>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"figs\"></a>All Figures</h2>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1.</span></a><p>Distribution of the 2 129 659 clusters of objects extracted from the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 catalogue. They are composed of three and four images that pass the soft astrometric test (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S2\">2</a>) that have a maximum angular separation between components that is smaller than 6&#8243;, that have absolute differences in <i>G</i> magnitudes of &lt; 4 mag, and that are found in regions of the celestial sphere where the mean field density is lower than 6&#8198;&#8197;&#215;&#8197;&#8198;10<sup>4</sup> objects deg<sup>&#8722;2</sup>. Lower density regions near the galactic centre can be explained by the filtering occurring in the on-board processing in order to prevent memory from saturating in such very dense regions of the sky (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R29\">Gaia Collaboration 2016</a>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a><p>Receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve of the ABCD, ABC, ABD, ACD, and BCD models based on the test set (TS) and validation set (VS) of observations. The upper panels show the entire ROC curves, whereas the lower panels concentrate on the low FPR regions of each curve. The classification performances of each model is evaluated through the computation of the area under each of the TS&#8211;ROC and VS&#8211;ROC curves (AUC).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a><p>Distribution of the 70 697 clusters composed of four images and 2 058 962 clusters composed of three images extracted from the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S2\">2</a>) with respect to their ERT probabilities (solid line). The distribution of the known lenses are represented as boxes, whereas the distribution of the 6,944 clusters resulting from the cross-match we performed between our entire list of clusters and our compiled list of quasars is depicted as a dotted line in each graph (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S9\">3.4.2</a>). In cases where clusters are composed of three images, the ERT probability corresponds to the maximum of the ERT probabilities returned by the ABC, ABD, ACD, and BCD models.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a><p>Finding charts of the 17 known GLs and 15 GL candidates contained in our catalogue of clusters (Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#APP2\">B</a>). They are ordered according to their ERT probabilities (upper left corner of each subplot). The common name of the known lenses is labelled in red in the lower left corner of each subplot, while the candidates we propose have their probabilities written in green fonts. Images [1], [2], [4&#8211;7], [9], [11], [13], [14], [16], [17], [19&#8211;23], [25&#8211;32] come from the Pan-STARRS survey (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R18\">Chambers et al. 2016</a>); images [12], [15], [18] come from the Digitized Sky Survey II (<a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R49\">Lasker et al. 1996</a>); and images [3], [8], [10], [24] come from the DES (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R21\">Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et al. 2016</a>). All images were collected from the ALADIN sky atlas (<a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R15\">Bonnarel et al. 2000</a>) in a field of view of 10.8&#8243;&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10.8&#8243; centred around the mean coordinates of the GL where east is to the left and north is up. Points are scaled according to the relative flux of the components with respect to the brightest image of each configuration.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5.</span></a><p>Distribution of the known and new candidate GLs in Galactic coordinates. The numbers in square brackets refer to the candidate numbers from Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#T3\">3</a> and Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#F4\">4</a>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" data-edps_ref=\"aa33802-18\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico ico-info\"></span>\n\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t<p>Initial download of the metrics may take a while.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\" src=\"/templates/source/js/metrics-tab.js\"></script>\n\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\n                                                    </div>\n                        <nav class=\"article\">\n Le Campion\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Laboratoire d\u2019Astrophysique de Bordeaux, Univ. Bordeaux, CNRS, B18N, All\u00e9e Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 33615 Pessac, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"E. Slezak\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l\u2019Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 Gravitational Lens Systems - III. A systematic blind search for new lensed systems\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2019/02/15\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2019/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"622\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A165\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2019A%26A...622A.165D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2019/02/aa33802-18.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"methods: data analysis\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"catalogs\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims&lt;i/&gt;. In this work, we aim to provide a reliable list of gravitational lens candidates based on a search performed over the entire &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; Data Release 2 (&lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2). We also aim to show that the astrometric and photometric information coming from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; satellite yield sufficient insights for supervised learning methods to automatically identify strong gravitational lens candidates with an efficiency that is comparable to methods based on image processing.&lt;i&gt;Methods&lt;i/&gt;. We simulated 106 623 188 lens systems composed of more than two images, based on a regular grid of parameters characterizing a non-singular isothermal ellipsoid lens model in the presence of an external shear. These simulations are used as an input for training and testing our supervised learning models consisting of extremely randomized trees (ERTs). These trees are finally used to assign to each of the 2 129 659 clusters of celestial objects extracted from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 a discriminant value that reflects the ability of our simulations to match the observed relative positions and fluxes from each cluster. Once complemented with additional constraints, these discriminant values allow us to identify strong gravitational lens candidates out of the list of clusters.&lt;i&gt;Results&lt;i/&gt;. We report the discovery of 15 new quadruply-imaged lens candidates with angular separations of less than 6\u2033 and assess the performance of our approach by recovering 12 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems with all their components detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 with a misclassification rate of fortuitous clusters of stars as lens systems that is below 1%. Similarly, the identification capability of our method regarding quadruply-imaged systems where three images are detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 is assessed by recovering 10 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems having one of their constituting images discarded. The associated misclassification rate varies between 5.83% and 20%, depending on the image we decided to remove.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"Agnello, A., &amp; Spiniello, C. 2018, MNRAS, submitted [arXiv:1805.11103]\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A.             dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: align=\"right\">1901</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.11</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.33(3)</td>\n<td align=\"right\">36 669</td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.58</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.1</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.09</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.3</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">WISE025942.9&#8211;163543</td>\n<td align=\"right\">3</td>\n<td align=\"right\">1577</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.76</td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\">13 751</td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.32</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.45</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.16</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.32</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b> The lens size and the maximum absolute difference in magnitude and colour, &#916;<i>G</i> and &#916;(<i>G</i><sub>BP</sub>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>G</i><sub>RP</sub>), are computed over all combinations of the lensed images while the field density is estimated within a radius of 30&#8243; around the system. The numbers in parentheses in Col. &#916;(<i>G</i><sub>BP</sub>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>G</i><sub>RP</sub>) correspond to the number of images that were used in the computation of the maximum absolute difference in colour. Four image configurations are processed using the ERT model ABCD, as well as using all the ABC, ABD, ACD, and BCD models based on the appropriate combination of images (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S3\">3</a>). Three image configurations are processed using models ABC, ACD, ABD, and BCD.</p>\n<div><a name=\"TFN1\" id=\"TFN1\"></a><sup>(a)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">J2145+6345 and DESJ0405&#8211;3308 are not contained in the original list of known gravitational lenses from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R24\">Ducourant et al. (2018)</a> as their discovery was announced after the list was compiled (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R51\">Lemon et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR6\" id=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R6\">Anguita et al. 2018</a>, respectively).</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN2\" id=\"TFN2\"></a><sup>(b)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">J2145+6345, SDSS1004+4112, DESJ0405&#8211;3308, and RXJ0911+0551 are not part of the final catalogue of clusters (Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#APP2\">B</a>) because they are found in regions of high stellar density (J2145+6345), because one of their images does not pass the soft astrometric test (DESJ0405&#8211;3308 and RXJ0911+0551), or because the angular size is too large (SDSS1004+4112).</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN3\" id=\"TFN3\"></a><sup>(c)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">For J1721+8842, we selected the configuration of four images out of the five images available for which the ERT probabilities was the highest (0.91). Alternative combinations implying image with <i>Gaia</i> source identifier 1729026466114871296 provide ERT probabilities between 0 and 0.05.</p></div>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" data-edps_ref=\"aa33802-18\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico ico-info\"></span>\n\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t<p>Initial download of the metrics may take a while.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\" Wambsganss\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Zentrum f\u00fcr Astronomie der Universit\u00e4t Heidelberg, Astronomisches Rechen-Institut, M\u00f6nchhofstr. 12-14, 69120 Heidelberg, Germany\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"International Space Science Institute (ISSI), Hallerstra\u00dfe 6, 3012 Bern, UK\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"J.-F. Le Campion\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Laboratoire d\u2019Astrophysique de Bordeaux, Univ. Bordeaux, CNRS, B18N, All\u00e9e Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 33615 Pessac, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"E. Slezak\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l\u2019Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 Gravitational Lens Systems - III. A systematic blind search for new lensed systems\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2019/02/15\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2019/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"622\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A165\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2019A%26A...622A.165D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2019/02/aa33802-18.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"methods: data analysis\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"catalogs\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims&lt;i/&gt;. In this work, we aim to provide a reliable list of gravitational lens candidates based on a search performed over the entire &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; Data Release 2 (&lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2). We also aim to show that the astrometric and photometric information coming from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; satellite yield sufficient insights for supervised learning methods to automatically identify strong gravitational lens candidates with an efficiency that is comparable to methods based on image processing.&lt;i&gt;Methods&lt;i/&gt;. We simulated 106 623 188 lens systems composed of more than two images, based on a regular grid of parameters characterizing a non-singular isothermal ellipsoid lens model in the presence of an external shear. These simulations are used as an input for training and testing our supervised learning models consisting of extremely randomized trees (ERTs). These trees are finally used to assign to each of the 2 129 659 clusters of celestial objects extracted from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 a discriminant value that reflects the ability of our simulations to match the observed relative positions and fluxes from each cluster. Once complemented with additional constraints, these discriminant values allow us to identify strong gravitational lens candidates out of the list of clusters.&lt;i&gt;Results&lt;i/&gt;. We report the discovery of 15 new quadruply-imaged lens candidates with angular separations of less than 6\u2033 and assess the performance of our approach by recovering 12 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems with all their components detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 with a misclassification rate of fortuitous clusters of stars as lens systems that is below 1%. Similarly, the identification capability of our method regarding quadruply-imaged systems where three images are detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 is assessed by recovering 10 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems having one of their constituting images discarded. The associated misclassification rate varies between 5.83% and 20%, depending on the image we decided to remove.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"Agnello, A., &amp; Spiniello, C. 2018, MNRAS, submitted [arXiv:1805.11103]\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. type=\"text/javascript\">\n\tjQuery(function ($) {\n\t    var source = function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"wrap\">                                  </div>                  \n align=\"right\">303.725615</td>\n<td align=\"right\">&#8722;30.414491</td>\n<td align=\"right\">2465</td>\n<td align=\"right\">13 751</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.48</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.74</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">[30]</td>\n<td align=\"left\">011559515+562506671</td>\n<td align=\"right\">3</td>\n<td align=\"right\">18.997963</td>\n<td align=\"right\">56.418524</td>\n<td align=\"right\">2756</td>\n<td align=\"right\">45 837</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.70</td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.60</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b> The finding charts depicting all of these candidates are given in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#F4\">4</a>. The numbers in parentheses in Col. &#916;(<i>G</i><sub>BP</sub>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>G</i><sub>RP</sub>) correspond to the number of images that were used in the computation of the maximum absolute difference in colour.</p>\n<p>\nFig. 4. \n<p>Finding charts of the 17 known GLs and 15 GL candidates contained in our catalogue of clusters (Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#APP2\">B</a>). They are ordered according to their ERT probabilities (upper left corner of each subplot). The common name of the known lenses is labelled in red in the lower left corner of each subplot, while the candidates we propose have their probabilities written in green fonts. Images [1], [2], [4&#8211;7], [9], [11], [13], [14], [16], [17], [19&#8211;23], [25&#8211;32] come from the Pan-STARRS survey (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R18\">Chambers et al. 2016</a>); images [12], [15], [18] come from the Digitized Sky Survey II (<a name=\"InR49\" id=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R49\">Lasker et al. 1996</a>); and images [3], [8], [10], [24] come from the DES (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R21\">Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et al. 2016</a>). All images were collected from the ALADIN sky atlas (<a name=\"InR15\" id=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R15\">Bonnarel et al. 2000</a>) in a field of view of 10.8&#8243;&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10.8&#8243; centred around the mean coordinates of the GL where east is to the left and north is up. Points are scaled according to the relative flux of the components with respect to the brightest image of each configuration.</p>\n<img alt=\"image\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18-fig4.jpg\" width=\"1200\" height=\"1204\" />\n</p>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" data-edps_ref=\"aa33802-18\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico Le Campion\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Laboratoire d\u2019Astrophysique de Bordeaux, Univ. Bordeaux, CNRS, B18N, All\u00e9e Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 33615 Pessac, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"E. Slezak\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l\u2019Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 Gravitational Lens Systems - III. A systematic blind search for new lensed systems\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2019/02/15\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2019/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"622\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A165\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2019A%26A...622A.165D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2019/02/aa33802-18.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"methods: data analysis\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"catalogs\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims&lt;i/&gt;. In this work, we aim to provide a reliable list of gravitational lens candidates based on a search performed over the entire &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; Data Release 2 (&lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2). We also aim to show that the astrometric and photometric information coming from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; satellite yield sufficient insights for supervised learning methods to automatically identify strong gravitational lens candidates with an efficiency that is comparable to methods based on image processing.&lt;i&gt;Methods&lt;i/&gt;. We simulated 106 623 188 lens systems composed of more than two images, based on a regular grid of parameters characterizing a non-singular isothermal ellipsoid lens model in the presence of an external shear. These simulations are used as an input for training and testing our supervised learning models consisting of extremely randomized trees (ERTs). These trees are finally used to assign to each of the 2 129 659 clusters of celestial objects extracted from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 a discriminant value that reflects the ability of our simulations to match the observed relative positions and fluxes from each cluster. Once complemented with additional constraints, these discriminant values allow us to identify strong gravitational lens candidates out of the list of clusters.&lt;i&gt;Results&lt;i/&gt;. We report the discovery of 15 new quadruply-imaged lens candidates with angular separations of less than 6\u2033 and assess the performance of our approach by recovering 12 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems with all their components detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 with a misclassification rate of fortuitous clusters of stars as lens systems that is below 1%. Similarly, the identification capability of our method regarding quadruply-imaged systems where three images are detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 is assessed by recovering 10 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems having one of their constituting images discarded. The associated misclassification rate varies between 5.83% and 20%, depending on the image we decided to remove.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"Agnello, A., &amp; Spiniello, C. 2018, MNRAS, submitted [arXiv:1805.11103]\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. type=\"text/javascript\">\n\tjQuery(function ($) {\n\t    var source = function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"wrap\">                                  </div>                  \n Transitional//EN\" \"\">\n\n    <div id=\"annex\">\n      <h2 class=\"sec\">Table 2. </h2>\n      <p>Range of parameters explored to produce the simulated lens catalogues from a NSIEg lens model.</p>\n      <div class=\"tab\">\n        <table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" rules=\"groups\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">Explored</th>\n<th align=\"center\" colspan=\"6\">NSIEg parameters</th>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\"></th>\n<th colspan=\"6\"><hr /></th>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">range</th>\n<th align=\"right\"><i>b</i></th>\n<th align=\"right\"><i>q</i></th>\n<th align=\"right\"><i>s</i></th>\n<th align=\"right\"><i>&#947;</i></th>\n<th align=\"right\"><i>&#969;</i></th>\n<th align=\"right\"><i>x</i><sub>s</sub>, <i>y</i><sub>s</sub></th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">Range start</td>\n<td align=\"right\">1</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.2</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0&#176;</td>\n<td align=\"right\">&#8722;1</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">Step</td>\n<td align=\"right\">&#8211;</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.05</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.01</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.01</td>\n<td align=\"right\">5&#176;</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.02</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">Range end</td>\n<td align=\"right\">&#8211;</td>\n<td align=\"right\">1</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.3</td>\n<td align=\"right\">0.3</td>\n<td align=\"right\">175&#176;</td>\n<td align=\"right\">1</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b> A detailed description of these parameters is provided in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#APP1\">A</a>.</p>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico Le Campion\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Laboratoire d\u2019Astrophysique de Bordeaux, Univ. Bordeaux, CNRS, B18N, All\u00e9e Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 33615 Pessac, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"E. Slezak\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Universit\u00e9 C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, Observatoire de la C\u00f4te d\u2019Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire Lagrange, Boulevard de l\u2019Observatoire, CS 34229, 06304 Nice, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 Gravitational Lens Systems - III. A systematic blind search for new lensed systems\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2019/02/15\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2019/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"622\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A165\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2019A%26A...622A.165D\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2019/02/aa33802-18.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"methods: data analysis\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"catalogs\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims&lt;i/&gt;. In this work, we aim to provide a reliable list of gravitational lens candidates based on a search performed over the entire &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; Data Release 2 (&lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2). We also aim to show that the astrometric and photometric information coming from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; satellite yield sufficient insights for supervised learning methods to automatically identify strong gravitational lens candidates with an efficiency that is comparable to methods based on image processing.&lt;i&gt;Methods&lt;i/&gt;. We simulated 106 623 188 lens systems composed of more than two images, based on a regular grid of parameters characterizing a non-singular isothermal ellipsoid lens model in the presence of an external shear. These simulations are used as an input for training and testing our supervised learning models consisting of extremely randomized trees (ERTs). These trees are finally used to assign to each of the 2 129 659 clusters of celestial objects extracted from the &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 a discriminant value that reflects the ability of our simulations to match the observed relative positions and fluxes from each cluster. Once complemented with additional constraints, these discriminant values allow us to identify strong gravitational lens candidates out of the list of clusters.&lt;i&gt;Results&lt;i/&gt;. We report the discovery of 15 new quadruply-imaged lens candidates with angular separations of less than 6\u2033 and assess the performance of our approach by recovering 12 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems with all their components detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 with a misclassification rate of fortuitous clusters of stars as lens systems that is below 1%. Similarly, the identification capability of our method regarding quadruply-imaged systems where three images are detected in &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2 is assessed by recovering 10 of the 13 known quadruply-imaged systems having one of their constituting images discarded. The associated misclassification rate varies between 5.83% and 20%, depending on the image we decided to remove.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"Agnello, A., &amp; Spiniello, C. 2018, MNRAS, submitted [arXiv:1805.11103]\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. Agnello;citation_author=H. Lin;citation_author=N. href=\"/component/services/\" >Reader's services</a></li><li class=\"item-127\"><a href=\"/news\" >News</a></li></ul>\n</nav>\n            </div>\n\n            <div id=\"search\" class=\"hidden\">\n    <div class=\"wrap-search\">\n        <form action=\"/component/solr/?task=quick_search\" method=\"post\">\n            <div class=\"wrap\">\n            <div class=\"inputs\">\n                <input type=\"text\" name=\"q\" />\n                <button type=\"submit\" value=\"search\">\n                    <span class=\"ico ico-search\" title=\"Search\"></span>\n                </button>\n            </div> \n                            <div class=\"s_volume_page\">\n                    <a href=\"/component/searcharticle/?by=vol-page\">Access by volume/page</a>\n                </div>\n                        </div>\n\n            <div class=\"advanced\"><a href=\"/component/solr/\">Advanced Search</a></div>\n        </form>\n    </div>\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\">\n\tjQuery(function ($) {\n\t    var source = function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"wrap\">                                  </div>                  \n              </div>\n                    </header>\n\n        <main class=\"aa\" id=\"main\">\n\n            <!--div class=\"wrap\">\n             <p>Message placeholder</p>\n            </div-->\n\n            \n            \n              \n              \n            \n            \n            <div class=\"wrap\" >\n                              \n<div class=\"breadcrumbs\">\n\n\n\n<a href=\"/\"                     \n<div id=\"system-message-container\">\n</div>\n                      \n\n                      \n                                              <div class=\"flexme flexme-article\">\n                        <div class=\"article-content\">\n                                <div>\r\n    \n<div class=\"special_article green\">Free Access</div>\n    \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"ASCII\" standalone=\"yes\"?>\n<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\" \"\">\n\n    <div id=\"annex\">\n      <h2 class=\"sec\">Table B.1. </h2>\n      <p>Description of the fields contained in the <i>Gaia</i> GraL catalogue of clusters from <i>Gaia</i> DR2 sources.</p>\n      <div class=\"tab\">\n        <table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" rules=\"groups\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"right\">Num.</th>\n<th align=\"right\">Field name</th>\n<th align=\"center\">Unit</th>\n<th align=\"left\">Description</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">1.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>row</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">Unique identifier of the row in the catalogue. Each combination of the <tt>name</tt> and the <tt>SourceId</tt> is always associated with a unique <tt>row</tt>.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">2.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>name</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">Unique identifier of the cluster. This identifier is based on the mean position of the images of the cluster taken in sexagesimal coordinates.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">3.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>nimg</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">The number of images constituting the cluster (<tt>nimg</tt> &#8712;{3,4}).</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">4.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>size</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(&#8243;)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">The maximum angular separation between any two images of the cluster (<tt>size</tt> &#8804;6&#8243;).</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">5.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>known</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">Identifier in the list of known and candidate lenses from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#R24\">Ducourant et al. (2018)</a>. Empty if this cluster is not recognized as a known or candidate lens.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">6.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>density</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(obj. deg<sup>&#8722;2</sup>)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">The mean density of objects surrounding the cluster, estimated by counting the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 objects falling in a 30&#8243; radius around one of its constituent members (<tt>density</tt> &#8804;6&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>4</sup> objects deg<sup>&#8722;2</sup>).</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">7.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>dmag</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(mag)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">The maximum absolute difference in the <i>G</i> magnitude, &#916;<i>G</i>, between the images of the cluster (<tt>dmag</tt> &#8804; 4 mag).</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">8.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>dcolor</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(mag)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">The maximum absolute difference in colour, &#916;(<i>G</i><sub>BP</sub>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>G</i><sub>RP</sub>), between the images of the cluster. Empty if fewer than two images have colour information (i.e. <tt>BPmag</tt> or <tt>RPmag</tt> is empty).</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">9.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>ncolor</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">The number of images having colour information that are used in the computation of <tt>dcolor</tt>.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">10.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>P</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">ERT probability associated with this cluster (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/02/aa33802-18/aa33802-18.html#S3\">3</a>).</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">If <tt>nimg</tt> = 4, then this parameter corresponds to the ERT probabilities computed based on the ABCD model.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">If <tt>nimg</tt> = 3, then this field is taken as the maximum of <tt>PABC</tt>, <tt>PABD</tt>, <tt>PACD</tt>, and <tt>PBCD</tt>.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">11.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>PABC</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">ERT probability computed based on the ABC model. Empty if <tt>nimg</tt> = 4.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">12.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>PABD</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">ERT probability computed based on the ABD model. Empty if <tt>nimg</tt> = 4.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">13.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>PACD</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">ERT probability computed based on the ACD model. Empty if <tt>nimg</tt> = 4.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">14.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>PBCD</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">ERT probability computed based on the BCD model. Empty if <tt>nimg</tt> = 4.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan=\"4\"><hr /></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">15.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>SourceId</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">Unique source identifier from <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">16.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>RA</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(&#176;)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">Right ascension of the source in ICRS coordinates from <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">17.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>Dec</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(&#176;)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">Declination of the source in ICRS coordinates from <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">18.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>Gmag</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(mag)</td>\n<td align=\"left\"><i>G</i>-band mean magnitude from <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">19.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>BPmag</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(mag)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">Integrated BP mean magnitude from <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">Empty if no BP magnitude is available.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\">20.</td>\n<td align=\"right\">\n<tt>RPmag</tt></td>\n<td align=\"center\">(mag)</td>\n<td align=\"left\">Integrated RP mean magnitude from <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"right\"></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"left\">Empty if no RP magnitude is available.</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201833802\" data-edps_ref=\"aa33802-18\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico ico-info\"></span>\n\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t<p>Initial download of the metrics may take a while.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\" var collapse_content_selector = $(this).attr('href');\n          var toggle_switch = $(this);\n          $(collapse_content_selector).toggle(function() {\n            if ($(this).css('display') == 'none') {\n              toggle_switch.html('More');\n            } else {\n              toggle_switch.html('Less');\n            }\n          });\n        });\n      });\n    });\n  </script>\n            <div class=\"articles\">\n                      <a href=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2018/08/aa33337-18/aa33337-18.html\" class=\"title\">Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 gravitational lens systems \u2014 I. New quadruply imaged quasar candidates around known quasars</a>\n            <br />\n    \n          A&A 616, L11 (2018)<br />\n        <div class=\"separator\"></div>\n                            <a href=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/08/aa34573-18/aa34573-18.html\" class=\"title\">Gaia GraL: Gaia DR2 gravitational lens systems \u2014 IV.
